sourceDesc.bibl: Chicago Foreign Language Press Survey, 1936-1941, Works Projects Administration, Chicago Public Library Omnibus Project

revisionDesc.change: Initial TEI transcription from PanGeo Partners, Inc.

body.p: Financial interests in the East are raising a howl of protest the proposed appointment of a farmer as a member of the Board of the Federal Reserve Bank. It is claimed that such an appointment would indicate a trend toward class and Bolshevism, in spite of the fact that the proposal does not suggest that any particular class be represented. However, under the existing rules it is expressly understood that the Board is to consist of bankors exclusively.

Experience has shown that the polices of the Bank are not formulated with a view to the interests of agriculture. Its directors are all big bankers, and its credit system is based on short-term credits only, Mostly thirty, sixty, and ninety days. This suits the purposes of business and industry, but is practically useless to farmers and stock breeders, who, as a rule, need credit for from one to three years. It seems clear that this institutions could be of
much greater service if a man with a thorough knowledge of the needs of the farmers were appointed to its Board of Directors.

The big bankers have always taken it for that their opinions should be decisive in all of this nation's wealth. But the Senate proposal concedes, in that those who produce this wealth should also have something to to be made of it.

It must be remembered that this addition of one farmer member to the Board, which could not be dominated by him. But he would, at least, be in to keep they would have us believe that about to tirely unfounded, and its the people. The fact is that if all the they could not possibly fiasco out of the reserve bank than has been made of it by the professional
